title: Reading Comprehension Strategies

vocab.definition: The most important point or message in a story or text
Small pieces of information that tell more about the main idea
To guess what might happen next in a story
A person or animal in a story

teachingNotes: Use picture books and short texts. Model thinking aloud while reading. Practice asking questions before, during, and after reading.

sample.question: What should you do before you start reading a new book?
expectedAny: look at the cover and pictures
predict what it might be about
think about what you already know

sample.question: What is the main idea?
expectedAny: what the story is mostly about

sample.question: What does it mean to predict?
Name one question word you can ask.
How can pictures help you understand?
What should you do if you forget what you read?

truefalse.question: Good readers ask questions while they read.
The main idea is a small detail.
expectedAny: main idea is the big idea

truefalse.question: Predictions are guesses about what might happen next.
Pictures can give clues about the story.
Details are the same as the main idea.
Asking 'why' can help you understand reasons in a story.
You should never reread a page.

multiplechoice.question: Which is the best way to find the main idea of a story?
choices: Think about what the story is mostly about
expectedAny: main idea is what the whole story is about

multiplechoice.question: Which is a detail?
choices: The story is about a brave girl.
She climbs the tall tree to save the cat.

multiplechoice.question: Which strategy can help you understand?
Which clue can help figure out a new word?
Which question word asks about a place?
Which should you do if you are confused?

fillintheblank.question: When I read about a dog who saves a child, the _____ is the dog and the main idea is about _____.
Small pieces of information are called ________.
The ________ idea is what the text is mostly about.
When I make a ________, I guess what might happen next.
I can look at the ________ to help me understand.
I ask ________ like who, what, where, when, why, and how.
I can ________ a page if I forget what I read.

shortanswer.question: How can making predictions help you understand what you read?
expectedAny: keeps you thinking about the story
gets you ready for what might happen

shortanswer.question: What is one way to find the main idea?
expectedAny: think about what the story is mostly about

shortanswer.question: Why is it helpful to ask questions while reading?
How do pictures help you understand a story?
Give an example of a detail from a story about a birthday.
What should you do if a page is confusing?
How would you summarize a short story about a team that wins a game?
expectedAny: who, what, where, when, how it ended
